subSections.title: Chinese
subSections.text:
{{zh-forms|s=鸟}}
[[File:Harpyhaliaetus coronatus.jpg|thumb|240px]]

subSections.title: Glyph origin
Etymology
subSections.text:
Originally pronounced with a {{IPAchar|/t-/}} initial (compare {{och-l|島|island}}). In many dialects, it changed to a {{IPAchar|/n-/}} initial to avoid homophony with the vulgar word {{zh-l|屌|penis}}, which may ultimately have developed from the sense “bird”. Birds/fowl are characteristically associated with Chinese slangs for genitalia; compare {{zh-l|*雀|sparrow > penis}} and {{zh-l|*雞|chicken > penis}}.

Alternatively, {{zh-ref|Schuessler (2007)}} hypothesised that the {{IPAchar|/n-/}} initial form for “bird” may be unrelated to the {{IPAchar|/t-/}} form. Instead, it may be connected with the Tai-Kadai word for bird; confer {{cog|tai-pro|*C̬.nokᴰ||bird}}, whence {{cog|th|นก}}.

The {{IPAchar|/t-/}} form may be derived from {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*daw||bird}}, cognate with {{cog|kar-pro|*thoᴮ||bird}} and {{cog|tbq-bdg-pro|*daw/dow||bird}}.

Etymology 1
subSections.text:
{{wikipedia|lang=ja}} {{wikipedia|Bird}} [[File:Bird_Diversity_2011.png|thumb|250px|{{m|ja|鳥|tr=tori}}: various kinds of '''[[bird|birds]]'''.]]
{{ja-kanjitab|とり|yomi=k}} {{IPAfont|⟨to2ri⟩}} → {{IPAchar|/tori/}} From {{inh|ja|ojp|sort=とり|-}}. Probably cognate with {{cog|okm|-}} {{m|ko|ᄃᆞᆰ|tr=tolk}}, modern {{cog|ko|닭||fowl; chicken}}. May also be related to the {{cog|ja|-}} verb {{m|ja|飛ぶ|tr=tobu||to fly}}.
